info.title: Social Engineering Awareness
info.description: This quiz tests your knowledge on social engineering tactics and how to defend against them.

questions.question: What is Social Engineering in cybersecurity?
options: A method of hacking using software exploits
A technique to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information
A form of phishing that targets IT administrators
A security practice used to enhance system protection
questions.answer: A technique to trick individuals into revealing sensitive information

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of pretexting?
options: A scammer impersonating a bank representative to obtain account details
A fake website designed to steal login credentials
A USB device infected with malware left in an office
An employee accidentally clicking on a phishing email
questions.answer: A scammer impersonating a bank representative to obtain account details

questions.question: What is tailgating in the context of social engineering?
options: A hacker following an authorized employee into a restricted area
A phishing attack disguised as a legitimate email
An email scam that tricks users into downloading malware
A method used by organizations to prevent cyber threats
questions.answer: A hacker following an authorized employee into a restricted area

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of baiting?
options: A cybercriminal leaving an infected USB drive in a workplace
An attacker sending a fake IT support request
A fake website requesting users to enter their passwords
A ransomware attack that locks users out of their systems
questions.answer: A cybercriminal leaving an infected USB drive in a workplace

questions.question: What is a common characteristic of social engineering attacks?
options: They rely on exploiting human psychology rather than technical vulnerabilities
They only affect large organizations and government agencies
They use brute force attacks to gain access to systems
They are primarily based on software vulnerabilities
questions.answer: They rely on exploiting human psychology rather than technical vulnerabilities

questions.question: How can organizations protect against social engineering attacks?
options: By educating employees on recognizing and responding to threats
By installing the latest antivirus software
By enforcing strict password policies only
By monitoring social media activity of employees
questions.answer: By educating employees on recognizing and responding to threats

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of social engineering?
options: Using a fraudulent email to trick an employee into revealing credentials
Guessing a password using brute force techniques
Calling an employee while impersonating IT support
Leaving a malware-infected USB drive in a parking lot
questions.answer: Guessing a password using brute force techniques

questions.question: What should you do if someone claiming to be IT support asks for your password?
options: Provide the password only if they sound legitimate
Confirm their identity through an official company channel before sharing any information
Write it down and give it to them later
Change your password immediately and notify your coworkers
questions.answer: Confirm their identity through an official company channel before sharing any information

questions.question: Why do attackers use social engineering instead of technical hacking methods?
options: It is easier to manipulate people than to exploit systems
It requires advanced programming knowledge
It is more expensive to carry out
It is more secure for the attacker
questions.answer: It is easier to manipulate people than to exploit systems

questions.question: What should you do if you suspect a social engineering attack?
options: Ignore it and hope it doesn't happen again
Report it to your company's security team immediately
Share the details with your coworkers so they can take action
Confront the attacker and ask them to stop
questions.answer: Report it to your company's security team immediately
